title-group.article-title: Provocative Texts: Li Zhi, Montaigne, and the Promotion of Critical Judgment in Early Modern Readers

abstract.p: The radical Chinese intellectual Li Zhi (1527-1602) is known for his habit of opposing traditional interpretations of canonical texts. Juxtaposing Li Zhi's irreverent strategies of reading and writing with those of his French contemporary, the essayist Michel de Montaigne (1533-1592), this paper casts both writers as responding to analogous social and economic pressures characteristic of the developing early modern world. Unlike earlier generations, who sought to recapture authorial intentions, readers in this era increasingly took upon themselves the authority to impose meaning subjectively upon texts. And the books they composed, in turn, provoked impassioned debate among readers.
